entry.title: Give your Joule Agents ü§ñ the gift of Memory üí≠, with Hana Cloud ‚ú®
entry.content:
When Joule agents can write/read memories in SAP HANA Cloud, they:

  • Remember business facts at scale (supplier habits, contract quirks, SLA exceptions) ‚úÖ

  • Retrieve them fast & accurately with HANA Cloud Vector Engine ‚ö°

  • Keep memories human-readable, sortable, and dead-simple to implement üß©

That means fewer repeated mistakes, smarter suggestions, and agents that actually learn with your business over time.

An example of some memories for an invoice exception agent.
You can make them as detailed or a simple as you want in the agent prompt!

 

 

How it works

  1. A simple ‚ÄúMemories‚Äù table

    Human-readable text + metadata (who/what it‚Äôs about, when learned, importance, TTL, etc.).

    Optional: a vector column for semantic search.

  2. Vector search for recall

    Store an embedding of each memory ‚Üí use approximate nearest neighbor (ANN) to fetch the right facts instantly (‚ÄúWhich supplier often uses expired POs?‚Äù). BM25 or other strategies are available. I love BM25's reliability for same-language and same-topic knowledge meshes.

  3. One tool your agent calls

    Add a tool (below) so your agent can append or update memories whenever it learns something new.

  4. Update the Agent prompt to have it use the memory well!

           Something like:

Before answering, search (memory.search_hana) with a concise query (supplier/invoice/PO terms; limit top_k‚â§8); 
use the results to tailor your response. 
Only write when you learn a new, stable, factual business detail; 
upsert (memory.upsert_hana) instead of inserting duplicates‚Äîtreat as duplicate if normalized context matches or vector similarity ‚â•0.86 and the same entity (supplier/invoice/PO) is involved; 
if duplicate, refresh last_seen_at (and occurrence_count if available). Format memories as one dense sentence in context 
(e.g., YYYY-MM-DD | INV-XXXX | Supplier ABC | PO 4500001123 | 4,980.00 EUR | expired PO used) 
and a brief actionable description; keep context ‚â§220 chars, use present tense. 
Set importance 1‚Äì5 (5 = critical risk) and ttl_days (low importance decays, 0 = never expires). 
Do not store ephemeral chatter or sensitive data; prefer patterns over one-offs. 
If you update or add a memory, mention it briefly to the user; otherwise be concise and never dump full tables unless asked.

 

Add two memory tools (Joule Skills)

"Add Memory" is a simple SQL Write

"Retrieve Memory" is a simple SQL Read, with semantic search (BM25+Embeddings)

 

 

Advanced memory patterns (that HANA makes easy) üöÄ

  • Disappearing memories (decay/TTL): small quirks fade unless they‚Äôre re-observed.

  • Hierarchical memories: supplier-site ‚Üí supplier ‚Üí region ‚Üí global policy.

  • World representations: keep a simple graph of relationships (supplier‚Üîplant, approver‚Üîcost center), or materialize views for fast joins.

  • Learning from mistakes: tag memories with resolution outcome so the agent prefers strategies that worked.

 

Result:

A living, human-readable knowledge fabric your Joule agents can trust.
It's fast, explainable, and always improving. ‚ú®

entry.title: Simplifying Field Service with AI in SAP FSM
entry.content:
Introduction:

SAP field service management operations set up for any new company settings requires careful planning, which has become much easier with the help of built in cloud AI features. With the help of these smart tools companies in FSM helps with much better decision making. Which also helps the technicians to complete their work more efficiently since they will be getting real-time support, faster & for instance access to the information which they require and smart scheduling. This results in lesser delays, and much improved service quality.

 Prerequisites for SAP Cloud FSM:

  • Must have a valid license for SAP AI Units.
  • Premium AI features must be activated in FSM tenant.
  • Sufficient Historical Data (1000 activities with the execution Stage should be equal to CLOSE status in order to train the system)


Key AI Features in SAP FSM:

Below is the breakdown of the core AI functionalities available

1. Intelligent Filtering

  1. Assignment Duration Prediction
  2. Activity Summary
  3. Equipment Summary

 

-> Intelligent Filtering:

Intelligent Filtering will help by showing the most relevant technicians only for the job and automatically sorting. which is like having a smart assistant that understands the input. Instead of checking each customer manually system will sort them based on the requirements of the job, then you will be getting a list of customers who passed the requirements which leads to lesser time consumption and better accuracy.
For example, imagine you're a dispatcher in FSM who is trying to assign a technician to a service job, you have list of technicians, but not all of them are suitable for all tasks, some might be far away, some might not be having the right skills, and others might already busy with other service jobs assigned previously. so based on the below points we can perform the intelligent filtering.

  • What the job needs (Like skills, tools, etc.)
  • Which technicians are available to perform the service task
  • Who is nearby to perform the service task
  • Who has done the similar job well previously.

Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • Lesser time consumption: No need to manually check the list of all customers.
  • Reduced errors: Selects only technicians who are qualified and are available.
  • Improved customer service: Faster and better matches which results in the quicker resolutions for the tasks.


Steps to Enable:

  1. Raise an Incident:
    • Go to your SAP support portal.
    • Create a request under the component: CEC-SRV-FSM-AI.
    • Mention that you have a valid license and want to activate Intelligent Filtering.
  2. SAP Will Enable the Feature:
    • Once the request is processed, SAP will activate the feature in your FSM environment.
  3. Verify in the FSM Portal:
    • Navigate to the Planning & Dispatching module.
    • You‚Äôll see technician suggestions ranked intelligently when assigning service calls.

Compared to the older Best Matching Technician plugin, Intelligent Filtering is smarter and much easier to use. The old plugin works based on business rules which has been set up for every company, like checking technician skills or distance. whereas Intelligent Filtering in FSM uses the AI to understand what exactly dispatcher is looking for in the technicians and it automatically suggests the best technicians available for the service task.  It is much faster, that means it supports natural language searches. And it also gives the extra insights like past equipment history (which is not available in the old plugin doesn‚Äôt offer).


-> Assignment Duration Prediction:

Assignment Duration Prediction can be seen during the dispatching of an activity which will provide the overview like how long it will take to complete the current service task, which technician will be suitable for this activity rather than dispatcher guessing how long it might take to complete the current service tasks.

It uses the data like below:

  • The type of service task which needs to be assigned
  • The technician‚Äôs past performance on the service tasks
  • Historical data which are similar to the current service task
  • Job priority and some other requirements

This will help the dispatchers to plan accurately and helps to avoid the delay.

 Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  •  Better scheduling: can avoid the overloading the technicians.
  • Lesser delays during the assignment of service tasks.

Steps to Enable:

  1. Training the (AI Model) system

You can do this in two easy ways:

  • Option A: Use the Settings Screen
    • Go to Settings and Configuration in FSM.
    • Click on Assignment Duration Prediction.
    • Select your training data and click Train.

 

  • Option B: Use a Sample Business Rule
    • Download the sample rule from SAP Help.
    • Upload it to your FSM system.
    • Add your technical contact and adjust the date range if needed.
    • Run the rule to train the model.
  1. Activate the Feature
  • Go to: Settings and Configuration ‚Üí Planning and Dispatching ‚Üí General Settings ‚Üí Activity Planning ‚Üí Additional Settings
  • Turn on the checkbox:
    ‚ÄúAllow assignment duration prediction for semi and fully automated scheduling‚Äù
  1. Start Using It
  • Use features like Auto-Scheduling or Best Matching Technician.
  • The system will now use predicted durations instead of planned ones when assigning jobs.

 

-> Activity Summary:

Activity summary is like an assistant who give you the overview of the activity like what technician was doing, it gives you the summarized explanation of activity in detail, it helps the dispatcher to understand the below points:

  • what types of jobs were completed by technicians?
  • how much time did they take to complete the activity?
  • Did any issue occur during the completion of activity?


Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • with the help of activity summary dispatcher can save time as he doesn't have to go through each and every activity
  • Dispatcher can quickly understand how team is performing the activity using this feature
  • Can quickly identify if there is any issue which is occurring multiple times
  • Better decisions could be made with the help of summaries


 Steps to Enable

  1. Raise a Support Request
    • Go to the SAP Support Portal
    • Create a request under the component: CEC-SRV-FSM-AI
    • Mention that you want to enable Activity Summary along with other features.
  2. SAP Will Enable the Feature
    • Once approved, SAP will activate it in your FSM system
  3. Check in the FSM Portal
    • Go to the Planning and Dispatching module
    • You‚Äôll see AI-generated summaries for completed jobs

 

-> Equipment Summary:

Equipment Summary is similar to activity summary where in the activity summary we will be getting the summary of the completed activity but in the equipment summary we will be getting the summary of the equipment which will be used in the service tasks. it provides the details of the equipment which will be used in the service tasks which will help the dispatcher to make better decisions like.

  • Dispatcher can see which equipment was used for which service activity
  • how often did technician used this equipment
  • if there is any issue related to this equipment that can be seen in the equipment summary along with that, we can also see the performance of the equipment over time

Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • it saves time by giving the summary of the equipment in an instance rather than going through the equipment history record
  • if there is any reoccurring issue that can be fixed with the help of this feature so it will be very useful for preventive maintenance activities


Steps to Enable:

  1. Go to Planning and Dispatching - Open the Planning and Dispatching module in FSM.
  2. Open a Service Call you can either click on a service call from the Dispatching Board or select one from the Service Calls list.
  3. Generate Equipment Summary
    • Inside the service call, go to the General Information tab.
    • Scroll down to the Insights section.
    • Click the button to generate the equipment summary.
  4. Review and Use the Summary
    • The system will show a short, AI-generated summary of the equipment‚Äôs history.

 

 

Conclusion:

SAP FSM‚Äôs AI features help the service teams to work much faster and smarter by reducing the manual effort and better decision making.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì Blog #1 in the Series
entry.content:
Organizations around the world are migrating their databases to the cloud, striving to increase operational efficiency, performance, and scalability while reducing costs. But not all databases are created equal.

SAP HANA Cloud is a cloud-native, in-memory database that delivers high performance, scalability, and powerful analytics. It lets you store, process, and query various types of data and models in a single system. Developers can build and deploy intelligent applications, rapidly and at scale. These are just a few of the reasons why so many companies have moved to SAP HANA Cloud.

The value is clear. In a recent study,[1]  IDC found that large enterprises could realize an annual average value of US$13.7 million by using SAP HANA Cloud. This benefit equates to $820,000 per SAP HANA Cloud database per year, with a three-year ROI of 352%. Isn‚Äôt that impressive?

The promise of SAP HANA Cloud is attractive for organizations considering a database migration. But you still need to make your business case to justify a modernization initiative.

To help you develop your argument, I‚Äôve created this blog series on the top 10 benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In each blog, I‚Äôll review some of the key features and capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud and explore how each one can help your organization realize critical business value. Let‚Äôs get started.

Multi-model engines

No enterprise relies on only one type of data. Depending on your business, you may be using relational, geospatial, graph, JSON, and vector data, for example. This data can be structured, semi-structured, or unstructured, including text and multimedia content. Some organizations funnel data into single-purpose databases that handle only certain data types. But that database specialization creates additional costs, management effort, and complexity.

SAP HANA Cloud handles diverse workloads within a unified system‚Äîprocessing relational, geospatial, knowledge graph, time series, and vector data for AI applications. This ability to support multi-modal AI, where systems comprehend and process information from various data types, adds versatility. Application developers can integrate diverse data sources into a single application with ease and users can query and blend diverse data types intuitively. Multi-modal AI also reduces the need for complex ETL processes between systems.

The multi-model capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud deliver value by improving productivity. Developers can accelerate the development of AI-infused intelligent applications thanks to native support for predictive modeling, similarity searches, and graph analysis. By reducing the barriers to business data access and enabling faster, more informed decision-making, SAP HANA Cloud can speed up decision-making and improve overall business effectiveness.

Considering these benefits, IDC calculated that SAP HANA Cloud could enable overall productivity gains of 18%, creating an annual business value of $7.8 million. In the study, one entertainment industry executive summarized how the database delivered value for his company.

‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud is a more modernized system that has resulted in time savings for developers, analytics, and administration because of the robust integrated tools provided, templates, and modelling capabilities,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud has enabled my organization to make better business decisions and build better models, which drives business growth.‚Äù

Read more to build your business case

Multi-model engines are just one feature of SAP HANA Cloud that can accelerate your organization‚Äôs journey to modernization while reducing costs and maximizing efficiency. The following blogs in this series review additional capabilities that can help you build your business case while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

Watch out the next blog, which discusses SAP HANA Cloud‚Äôs infrastructure independence and next-generation application foundation.

entry.title: DP Agent Configuration With BTP Hana Cloud Instance
entry.content:
Hello Folks,

Recently, I faced some challenges while configuring the Data Provisioning (DP) Agent with an SAP HANA Cloud instance. In this blog, I want to highlight some important prerequisites, tips, and configuration steps that helped me resolve the issues. I hope this helps others going through the same process.

Before jumping into the configuration, ensure the following network prechecks are done properly:

1. Inbound IP Allowlist from the DP Agent Server

From your DP Agent host machine, make sure inbound IPs are allowed according to the BTP region where your HANA Cloud instance resides as per this guide BTP subaccount region network IP

Example: In my trial account, I allowed all TCP inbound IPs via the VM‚Äôs security group (see screenshot below).
However, for production environments, it‚Äôs recommended to allow only the specific subnet range based on your BTP subaccount region for better security.

2. IP Allowlist and DP Agent Enabled on HANA Cloud

On the SAP HANA Cloud instance side:

Ensure that IP allowlisting is properly configured to accept connections from your DP Agent server.

Also, enable DP Agent connectivity in the SAP HANA Cloud cockpit.

I‚Äôve attached screenshots showing these settings from my trial setup.

 

After completing these two network-level checks, you can verify connectivity using the telnet command to the HANA Cloud host and port. If that works, you're good to proceed with the agent configuration.

Now In terms of connectivity we are ready for the configuration.

configuration :

Before starting the actual configuration, make sure you have the following users ready.

1. Agent Admin HANA User - Generally DBADMIN User

2. HANA User Name for Agent Messaging - Technical user as per your requirements, refer to SAP help guide for user creation, roles, and privileges.

Users, Roles, and Privileges 

3. Most important

This step is often overlooked and causes issues during JDBC-based connectivity.

Make sure to update the following parameters in your dpagentconfig.ini file:

jdbc.enabled=true
jdbc.encrypt=true

If these are not set correctly, you may encounter JDBC errors while connecting to any BTP service.

These settings are mandatory for encrypted JDBC communication.

Once everything is in place, run the agentcli tool to configure your DP Agent.

Now you are able to register the agent in your SAP HANA Cloud instance

you can also verify the result from hana cloud instance.

If you're planning to set up data replication, I highly recommend checking out this excellent blog by haruki blog

 

I hope this post helps others avoid the common pitfalls I encountered.

Thanks for reading! Feel free to drop comments or questions ‚Äî I‚Äôd be happy to help

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì Blog #2 in the Series
entry.content:
In my previous blog, I discussed how SAP HANA Cloud delivers critical business benefits to organizations that migrate their database to the cloud. Advanced features such as multi-model engines allow enterprises to increase productivity and reduce complexity. In a recent study,[1]  IDC calculated that large enterprises can realize an annual average value of US$13.7 million by using SAP HANA Cloud.

Understanding how the specific capabilities of the database benefit your organization is key to helping you justify a cloud modernization initiative. Let‚Äôs look at two more capabilities that can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud: infrastructure independence and a next-generation application foundation.

Infrastructure independence

Your database requirements constantly evolve. To keep up with changing business conditions, customer requirements, and user demand, you need an infrastructure that matches your needs. A solution that offers vendor independence is key.

SAP HANA Cloud offers multi-cloud flexibility so you can run on your hyperscaler of choice. The cloud-native architecture runs on Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud Platform, Microsoft Azure, Alibaba Cloud, and soon, SAP data centers. You can choose a hyperscaler without fear of vendor lock-in.

 

Because it uses cloud-native technologies, the architecture offers consistent, high performance no matter which provider you choose. Automated failover and recovery features enhance resilience. Database administrators can provision new instances in just minutes. And elastic scaling capabilities respond to changing workload demands in real time.

SAP HANA Cloud also reduces the complexity of database operations. It simplifies integration across hybrid or multi-cloud environments and provides direct access to data in SAP applications. Because SAP HANA Cloud is a fully managed database-as-a-service (DBaaS) from SAP, your IT personnel are free to focus on value-added tasks. What‚Äôs more, SAP HANA Cloud covers your database, infrastructure, and management requirements, eliminating the need for a separate infrastructure contract with your hyperscaler.

The IDC study assessed the financial impact of infrastructure independence and the associated flexibility. After deploying SAP HANA Cloud, study participants reported a 33% efficiency boost for their infrastructure teams and said that database deployments were executed 38% faster. Considering the costs of IT staff management, unplanned downtime, and database infrastructure, IDC calculated a 35% lower annual total cost of ownership for SAP HANA Cloud over a three-year period.

According to one study participant with a large database environment,

‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud has enabled us to redirect IT staff to focus more on the production environment, new development, integration, and leveraging AI. Overall, this allows them to help drive revenue and increase productivity.‚Äù

Next-generation application foundation

To gain business value from modern, intelligent applications, you need a sophisticated database that can support multiple data types from various sources, process data in real time, and deliver insightful analytics.

SAP HANA Cloud is part of SAP Business Technology Platform, an open cloud platform with data management, analytics, AI, IoT, blockchain technologies and application development services. Together, SAP HANA Cloud and SAP BTP form a full-stack solution that includes powerful integration features and an intuitive interface, all under one commercial model.  In addition, SAP HANA Cloud is the trusted database that powers SAP‚Äôs mission-critical solutions, such as SAP Business Cloud, with multi-model engines and enterprise-grade performance and reliability.

SAP HANA Cloud also empowers developers to create intelligent applications using today‚Äôs most advanced technologies. With this database, teams can build applications that use generative AI, machine learning, and specialized engines to handle vectors, knowledge graphs, property graphs, and spatial processing. It also manages semi-structured JSON data with ACID compliance. The resulting applications are context-aware and offer secure connections to critical business data and curated data products from SAP.

This integrated approach allows applications to ingest and process data in multiple formats and from various sources, including SAP and third-party solutions. Users get live access to critical business information without data replication. Native connectivity to various data sources unifies disparate data streams, offering a single holistic view of your enterprise data. Applications can respond to events in real time, support automated processes, and enable ad-hoc decision-making using current and historical data.

 Having a next-generation application foundation adds IT, performance, and business enablement benefits, according to the IDC study. After adopting SAP HANA Cloud, participating organizations realized a 33% efficiency boost for their infrastructure teams. Query speed and response time increased by 31% and 29%, respectively. Enterprises processed 151% more data sources and 77% greater data volume (in terabytes) than in previous environments. Business operations improved, thanks to enhanced analytics that led to better business decisions, an accelerated application development process, and more agile deployment of database resources. Participants also realized end-user productivity gains of 18%, leading to annual gross revenue gains of nearly $40 million per organization.

A study participant who works in the healthcare industry summarized the value of SAP HANA Cloud.

‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud provides my organization the ability to apply parallel processes and maintain scalable databases,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAs a result, we have been able to build a lot of applications with machine learning and AI capabilities. With SAP HANA Cloud, it is easier to integrate these applications.‚Äù

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

entry.title: Avoiding Data Loss When Loading Initial Data with CSV Files in CAP
entry.content:
Introduction

When you start learning CAP, running cds add tiny-sample generates all the necessary sample artifacts, including a CSV file inside the db/data folder. Once deployed, the data from this CSV file is loaded as initial data into SAP HANA Cloud.

This mechanism seems convenient for loading initial data into SAP HANA Cloud for productive applications, doesn‚Äôt it?
However, there‚Äôs a catch. If you change the CSV data or modify the schema, the data in SAP HANA Cloud will be reinitialized with the CSV content ‚Äî including the data entered by users! Let‚Äôs take a look at what the documentation says:

On SAP HANA, only use CSV files for configuration data that can't be changed by application users. ‚Üí See CSV data gets overridden in the SAP HANA guide for details.

This is exactly the point I want to highlight in this article. At the same time, I‚Äôve also explored some alternative approaches and validated them.

 

Case1: New Development

When developing a new CAP application, you have the following options:

  • Option A: Do not use CSV files to register initial data for tables that will be maintained by the application users.
  • Option B: If both initial data and user-generated data need to coexist, define filter conditions in the .hdbtabledata file.

Option A is the simplest, if feasible. However, in some cases ‚Äî such as for master data ‚Äî the ability to quickly load initial data from CSV files is attractive. Below, let‚Äôs look at Option B in more detail.

 

Option B: Define filter conditions in the .hdbtabledata

1. Add a column called dataCategory to the table to distinguish between different types of data. (This is just an example; you can use any column as in identifier.) 

entity Books {
  key ID    : Integer;
      title : String;
      stock : Integer;
      dataCategory: String enum {
        system = 'S';
        user = 'U';
      }
}

2. Run the command cds build --production to generate an .hdbtabledata file in the gen/db/src/data folder. Copy this file to the db/src/static/csv folder, and then add an include_filter as shown below.  This ensures that the HDI container takes ownership only of the records specified by the filter. (Note: The values must be strings, even if the column‚Äôs data type is numeric.)

{
  "format_version": 1,
  "imports": [
    {
      ...,
      "import_settings": {
        "import_columns": [
          "ID",
          "TITLE",
          "STOCK",
          "DATACATEGORY"
        ],
        "include_filter": [
          { "DATACATEGORY" : "S" }
        ]
      },
      "column_mappings": {
        "ID": "ID",
        "TITLE": "title",
        "STOCK": "stock",
        "DATACATEGORY": "dataCategory"
      }
    }
  ]
}

3. Move the CSV file into the db/src/static/csv folder as well. Don't forget to set the dataCategory to "S".

ID,title,stock,dataCategory
1,Wuthering Heights,100,S
2,Jane Eyre,500,S

4. After the initial deployment, users update some of the records and insert one new entry, resulting in the following state (as shown in the result of a GET request):

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "dataCategory": "S", "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "dataCategory": "S", "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "dataCategory": "U", "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

5. When schema changes or updates to the initial data are applied, records with dataCategory = "S" are overwritten, while records with dataCategory = "U" remain untouched. For example, after adding a new column newField:

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "dataCategory": "S", "newField": null, "stock": 100, "title": "Wuthering Heights" },
    { "ID": 2, "dataCategory": "S", "newField": null, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "dataCategory": "U", "newField": null, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

 

Case 2: Accidentally Mixed Data

In some cases, custom data and pre-delivered data (from a CSV file) may accidentally end up in the same table governed by an HDI Table Data artifact (.hdbtabledata) without filter conditions to separate them. 

SAP Note 2922271 outlines how to handle this situation. Below, I‚Äôll walk you through the steps.

Note: The procedure described here applies to single-tenant applications. For multitenant scenarios, please refer to the documentation, as well as @Sekar_Somasundaram's  detailed blog post. 

 

Steps at a Glance

  • Delete the CSV file.
  • Make the .hdbtabledata artifact subject to undeploy.
  • Ensure that existing data is preserved during undeploy.

 

Current State of the Data

  • The CSV file initially contains the following data:

ID,title,stock
1,Wuthering Heights,100
2,Jane Eyre,500

  • After the initial deployment, users update some of the records and insert one new entry, resulting in the following state:

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

 

Step-by-Step: Deleting the CSV File After Initial Deployment

1. Delete the CSV file.

2. Add "src/gen/**/*.hdbtabledata" to db/undeploy.json as shown below:

[
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbview",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbindex",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbconstraint",
  "src/gen/**/*_drafts.hdbtable",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbcalculationview",
  "src/gen/**/*.hdbtabledata"
]

3. Copy gen/db/package.json to the db folder, and add the following parameters to the start script.

 --undeploy src/<mytable>.hdbtabledata --path-parameter src/<mytable>.hdbtabledata:skip_data_deletion=true

In my example, the package.json looks as follows:

{
  "name": "deploy",
  "dependencies": {
    "hdb": "^0",
    "@sap/hdi-deploy": "^5"
  },
  "engines": {
    "node": ">=18"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "start": "node node_modules/@sap/hdi-deploy/deploy.js --use-hdb --parameter com.sap.hana.di.table/try_fast_table_migration=true --undeploy src/gen/data/my.bookshop-Books.hdbtabledata --path-parameter src/gen/data/my.bookshop-Books.hdbtabledata:skip_data_deletion=true"
  }
}

4. Deploy the project. In the db-deployer log, you will see a message indicating that the existing data was not deleted.

[APP/TASK/deploy/0] OUT The "skip_data_deletion" make parameter is set; no data will be deleted from the target table "MY_BOOKSHOP_BOOKS"

As a result, the updated user data remains intact.

{
  "@odata.context": "$metadata#Books",
  "value": [
    { "ID": 1, "stock": 100, "title": "Updated" },
    { "ID": 2, "stock": 500, "title": "Jane Eyre" },
    { "ID": 3, "stock": 10, "title": "New Book" }
  ]
}

5. Before the next deployment, delete the db/package.json file to restore the original state. From this point on, even if the schema changes, the data will no longer be overridden.

 

Other Ways to Register Data

Besides using CSV files during deployment, you can load data through the following approaches as well:

  • Insert data via HTTP requests: Insert data after deployment using HTTP requests.
  • Upload CSV files through the Database Explorer: Upload CSV files directly from the Database Explorer.
  • For local testing: Place CSV files in the test/data folder instead of db/data (see: Location of CSV Files | capire).

* For CAP Java, configuration in application.yaml is required for loading CSV files from the test/data folder. Please find my Q&A below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/cap-java-csv-data-in-the-test-data-folder-not-loaded-duirng-local-testing/qaa-p/14227290#M4927381

 

Closing

A clear strategy on how to provide initial data must be defined upfront. CSV files are convenient but must be used with caution, particularly in productive environments. Applying best practices such as separating system and user data, leveraging .hdbtabledata filters, or considering alternative loading options will help maintain data integrity and protect user input across deployments.

 

References

  • CSV Data Gets Overridden (capire) 
  • I removed sample data (.csv file) from my project. Still, the data is deployed and overwrites existing data. (capire)

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì Blog #3 in the Series
entry.content:
Welcome back to my blog series on the value of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In the first two blogs, I discussed how features such as multi-model engines, infrastructure independence, and a next-generation application foundation all can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud.

In fact, we‚Äôve already seen powerful confirmation of the value of this database. For example, global consulting services provider CONTAX Inc. migrated to SAP HANA Cloud to gain the elasticity and scalability it needed to handle huge demands on its database resources. This modernization helped CONTAX expand its database capacity while reducing its overall memory footprint and cost by 25%.

That‚Äôs impressive. So how can you best estimate the benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud for your enterprise?

Many organizations want to migrate their database to the cloud because they want to build and deploy intelligent applications at scale. But that requires an advanced data landscape architecture‚Äîa database-as-a-service (DBaaS) for modernizing your applications. Let‚Äôs talk about two capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud that help you meet that need and deliver exceptional value: intelligent data tiering and multi-dimensional elastic scalability.

Intelligent data tiering

The exploding growth of business data is both a cost issue and a management challenge for your business. How can you store the data users need and make it easily accessible without busting the budget?

Traditional database technology requires that you choose between database performance and costs. Should you pay more to over-provision storage space so data can be easily persisted in case of growing demands? Or should you archive data to save money but make data harder to access?

With SAP HANA Cloud, you can strike the right balance for your business.

 Intelligent, multi-temperature data management features help you store data in tiers according to type, operational usefulness, access frequency, and scalability requirements. The database locates frequently accessed, business-critical ‚Äúhot‚Äù data in high-performance, in-memory storage, which facilitates real-time processing. ‚ÄúWarm‚Äù data requiring moderate access uses disk storage. Infrequently accessed ‚Äúcold‚Äù data can be stored in a lower-cost data lake optimized for long-term retention and compliance.

By combining tiered storage with advanced virtualization capabilities, SAP HANA Cloud reduces cost and complexity while enabling optimum overall performance. Applications and users can query data at any tier without needing to know where the data is stored. Automatic optimization based on data location and access patterns eliminates complex, costly ETL processes‚Äîwhile supporting both operational efficiency and analytical depth. Data tiering also simplifies application development by offering one interface to multiple data tiers. Developers can use that interface to query data for applications without needing to know where the data is stored.

A recent IDC study [1] assessed database performance impacts for organizations that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Query speed and response time improved by 31% and 29%, respectively. Backups executed 27% faster. Both data load time and recovery time were 24% faster.

‚ÄúData is more accessible with SAP HANA Cloud,‚Äù said one study participant. ‚ÄúIt is also available in real time and loads far quicker than our previous environment. Our data performance has enhanced.‚Äù

Multi-dimensional elastic scalability

Another way SAP HANA Cloud helps you balance performance and cost is by enabling elastic scalability for data processing and storage across multiple dimensions. In today‚Äôs dynamic database environments, short-term processing peaks caused by issues such as period-end reporting surges, seasonal transactions, or heavy analytics workloads can create havoc.

Elastic scalability lets you adjust compute and storage resources based on workload demands, in real time. The database ramps up resources during periods of high demand and then reduces them during low-usage times to conserve costs. Flexible resources include:

  • Performance classes, with flexible CPUs and memory ratios
  • Elastic compute nodes, on-demand resources provisioned in minutes for data-intensive OLAP workloads
  • Dynamic scalability, with individual storage tiers that allow the database to grow or shrink as needed

SAP HANA Cloud also includes elasticity features such as class-based dynamic workload routing, which automatically sends queries to the most appropriate compute resources. An ECN advisor analyzes historical workload patterns and creates optimal provisioning schedules. To prevent scaling events from disrupting application performance, SAP HANA Cloud offers built-in monitoring and workload routing capabilities.

These elastic scalability features help you respond rapidly to changing business needs, enabling optimal performance without over provisioning resources. These features make data more accessible to users while reducing infrastructure complexity. Together, they can help you drive operational agility and cost-effective resource management.

With these benefits in mind, IDC evaluated the infrastructure costs of surveyed companies that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Using its business value methodology, IDC concluded that the infrastructure costs of an SAP HANA Cloud environment were 20% less than a comparable database environment over a three-year period.

According to one study participant operating in the retail industry, ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud has given my organization the ability to scale and reduce redundancy, which are significant benefits.‚Äù

entry.title: Email Notification to Approvers After Purchase Order Creation in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Flexible Workflow framework is widely used to manage approval processes for business documents such as purchase requisitions, purchase orders, and supplier invoices. By default, approvers receive workflow notifications directly in their Fiori Launchpad inbox. 

While this works seamlessly within the system, many organizations also expect approvers to receive an email notification in addition to the in-app notification. This ensures that:

  • Approvers are alerted even when they are not logged in to SAP.
  • Important purchasing decisions are not delayed.
  • The workflow process remains transparent and efficient.

To meet this requirement, SAP provides standard tools such as Workflow Scenario Management, Email Templates, and Email Transmission Monitoring. These enable businesses to configure and send customized email notifications for workflow tasks like purchase order approvals.

In the following blog, I will walk through a simple scenario where an approver receives an email notification after the creation of a purchase order.

Applications Involved:

Manage Workflow Scenarios

Maintain Email Templates 

Monitor Email Transmission

Step-by-Step Process

Step 1: Identify the Workflow Task

Why: This app helps us find the workflow task ID linked to the purchase order approval process. Without identifying the correct task, we cannot map the notification to the right workflow step.
What you‚Äôll do: Open the workflow scenario for Purchase Orders and note the task ID to be used.

how you‚Äôll do:

  • Open the Manage Workflow Scenarios app.
  • Select the relevant workflow (in this case, Purchase Order Flexible Workflow).
  • Identify the Task ID that is triggered when a PO is sent for approval.

Step 2: Maintain the Email Template

Why: SAP delivers standard templates, but they are generic. We often need to customize the subject and body of the email with business-specific content (e.g., PO number, company code, approver details).
What you‚Äôll do: Copy the pre-delivered template SWF_CRT_NOTIFY_RECIPIENTS, rename it as per your scenario, and adjust the subject/body with standard fields.

how you‚Äôll do:

  • Go to the Maintain Email Templates app.
  • Search for the pre-delivered template:
     SWF_CRT_NOTIFY_RECIPIENTS

  • Copy this template and create your own version.
    • Suggested naming convention: <ScenarioID>_CRT_ALL

  • Modify the Subject and Body as per business requirements, using the available standard data fields.

Step 3: Trigger the Notification

Why: To test the configuration, you need to trigger a purchase order approval workflow. This ensures the system sends both the in-app notification and the newly configured email notification.
What you‚Äôll do: Create a purchase order with a flexible workflow enabled and check whether the approver receives the email.

how you‚Äôll do:

  • Create a Purchase Order and ensure Workflow process is enabled and approver mail-id available.
  • At every approval level, the approver will now receive:
    • A system notification in SAP Fiori, and
    • An email notification delivered to their inbox.

Step 4: Monitor Email Transmission

Why: Sometimes emails fail due to configuration issues or missing recipient details. This app helps track and troubleshoot all outbound email notifications triggered from SAP.
What you‚Äôll do: Open the app to review email logs and confirm if the notification was successfully delivered to the approver.

how you‚Äôll do:

  • Use the Monitor Email Transmission app.
  • Here, you can check whether the email was successfully triggered and delivered.
  • This app provides details of all outbound email activities, helping administrators track and troubleshoot.

Summary

With just a few simple steps ‚Äî identifying the workflow task, maintaining an email template, and monitoring the transmission ‚Äî organizations can ensure that approvers are notified both inside SAP and via email. This enhancement improves workflow efficiency, reduces approval delays, and provides a better user experience.

Useful SAP notes:

3395242 - Approval/Rejection notifications are not sent for Purchase Contract workflows

Regards,

Vinith K

entry.title: Build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology
entry.content:
What is SAP BTP Guidance Framework: The Guidance Framework provides clear direction and a structured approach to adopting SAP technologies. With this guidance, you can develop intelligent applications using advanced analytics, equipping your organization with a robust foundation to support agile innovation. For more details read this blog. 

In this blog post, we will look into how to build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. You can find this Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology pillar under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. 

It‚Äôs imperative that in today‚Äôs economy, data is more than just numbers‚Äîit‚Äôs the foundation of innovation, strategy, and growth backed by AI. Yet many organizations still struggle to unlock the full potential of their data and give it purpose. SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers a structured, four-phase approach that helps enterprises transform raw data into actionable insights while building a strong data-driven culture. 

The Four Phases of SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology 

1. Scoping & Baseline Analysis: In this phase you can set the foundation by: 

  • Defining the scope of investigation across business processes, organizational units, and data domains. 
  • Assessing current data architecture and capabilities. 
  • Identifying gaps, pain points, and opportunities for improvement. 

Benefit of this phase is that your business will have a clear baseline architecture, capability assessment, and prioritized opportunities. 

2. Business Outcomes & Solution Requirements: the focus in this phase shifts to aligning data with measurable business goals such as:  

  • Define specific, data-driven business outcomes. 
  • Analyze use cases that trace how raw data transforms into business value. 
  • Identify required data products and map end-to-end integration flows. 

This phase allows to clearly define business outcome definitions and solution context diagrams. 

 3. Capability Map & Solution Architecture: this phase transforms requirements into a target architecture by: 

  • Developing a capability map using SAP BTP Maturity Assessment 
  • Explore architecture options through traditional capability mapping or solution diagrams from the SAP Discovery Center. 
  • Validate the preferred architecture with proof-of-concepts. 

With this phase the target solution architecture is validated through capability mapping and pilots. 

 4. Data Governance & Roadmaps: this final phase ensures long-term sustainability: 

  • Conduct a maturity assessment for data governance and organizational roles. 
  • Define roles such as Chief Data Officer, Data Steward, and Governance Manager. 
  • Build a roadmap with clear clusters (e.g., implementation, operations, security). 

The key benefit of this phase is to define Data governance framework, organizational structure, and a roadmap for execution. 

What makes SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology stand out is that it‚Äôs not just about technology‚Äîit‚Äôs about data, people and processes. By integrating governance, roles, and organizational change management, it ensures that data initiatives aren‚Äôt just implemented but also adopted across the enterprise. For organizations aiming to thrive in a data-driven economy, SAP‚Äôs Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology provides more than a roadmap‚Äîit delivers a proven framework for turning data into business value and give it purpose. By combining architecture best practices with governance and cultural adoption, it helps enterprises evolve from simply managing data to truly innovating with it.

Why was this blog post created?

entry.title: Introduction to Alert Rule Sets in SAP HANA Cloud Central
entry.content:
SAP HANA Cloud has advanced its monitoring and alerting capabilities by introducing Alert Rule Sets. Building on previous alert configuration methods and REST API-based bulk management, Alert Rule Sets offer a graphical interface for bulk alert configuration accessible to all administrators without API expertise.

What Are Alert Rule Sets?

  • Enable configuration of multiple alert rules at once and apply them across one or more HANA Cloud instances.
  • Create reusable alert configurations usable across different environments such as development, testing, and production.
  • Each user can maintain up to 20 alert rule sets for better organization and flexibility.

Key Benefits

  • Operational Efficiency: Bulk management reduces manual configuration effort.
  • Scalability: Supports large enterprise deployments with complex environments.
  • Simplified Maintenance: Updating an alert rule set updates all associated instances.

How to Create and Manage Alert Rule Sets

Prerequisites

  • Requires SAP HANA Cloud administrator role for creating or updating alert rule sets.
  • SAP HANA Cloud viewer role suffices for read-only access.
  • Alert rule sets cannot be created or modified for Data Lake instances, which only support read-only alert viewing

Configuration Steps

  1. Navigate to the Alert Rules Configuration page and choose Alert Rule Sets. Then select Create Alert Rule Set.
  2. Create a new alert rule set by naming it and providing a description. Select Next to configure alert rules.
  3. Configure alert rules by selecting which alerts to include, adjusting thresholds, and setting their status. Select Next to configure instance. Select Create Now to save the set and jump to the review page without configuring instances that apply this alert rule set.
  4. Select target HANA Cloud instances to apply the rule set. Select Review.
  5. Review and apply the configuration to deploy. Select Save and Apply to create the set and apply it. If the process is successful, the time stamp of the application will be visible under the Last Applied field. Select Save to create the set without applying it to one or more instances.

View Alert Rule Sets

Navigate to the Alert Rules Configuration page, choose Alert Rule Sets to see a list of your sets. Select a row to see more information about the set, including its name, description, status, and alert rules that are part of the set. In the Instances section you can see if the set is Applied or Not Applied to the instances you chose. There are several reasons why an instance appears under the Not Applied section:

  • You have saved the set without applying it to the chosen instances.
  • There has been an error during the application, for example, a server problem.
  • You (or another user) have modified alert rules that are part of the set elsewhere, for example, in the basic configuration or in another set. For more information, see Using Alerts in SAP HANA Cloud Central.

Modify Alert Rule Sets

You can edit, rename, and delete the set from the details page or from the list page, choosing ... (More) in the Actions column.

After modifying alert rules in a set, reapply the set to your selected instances to incorporate the latest changes.

Best Practices for Alert Rule Sets

  • Use descriptive, consistent naming conventions (e.g., PROD-HighPerf-CriticalAlerts).
  • Establish a review schedule to maintain relevance as infrastructure evolves.
  • Maintain comprehensive documentation for governance and clarity.

The UI and API Bridge

  • Alert Rule Sets represent a convergence of REST API automation and a user-friendly UI.
  • API automation remains available for DevOps and infrastructure-as-code automation.
  • Both approaches can be combined for hybrid workflows.

Conclusion

Alert Rule Sets signify a critical advancement in SAP HANA Cloud‚Äôs alert management, enabling scalable, efficient, and consistent alert configuration across multiple instances. This feature supports enterprises as they grow their HANA Cloud deployments by simplifying alert management complexities and providing both powerful automation and ease of use.

With this tool, administrators gain enhanced operational efficiency and consistency, supporting hundreds of instances if needed, making monitoring more flexible and user-friendly.

entry.title: Introducing SAP HANA Cloud on SAP Cloud Infrastructure
entry.content:
We are pleased to share that SAP HANA Cloud is now generally available on SAP BTP powered by SAP Cloud Infrastructure. This new deployment option complements our existing offerings on hyperscaler platforms, addressing the growing demand for technological independence, local compliance, and data control.

About SAP Cloud Infrastructure

SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI) is SAP's own Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) platform, operated from SAP data centers around the globe. Built on OpenStack APIs, it provides hyperscale-like capabilities including compute, storage, and networking. Originally designed to run SAP cloud applications with high scalability, resilience, compliance, and security, SCI now also supports selected customer and partner workloads. To explore the platform and its features, visit the SAP Cloud Infrastructure Documentation.

How the new deployment fits into SAP's multi-cloud strategy

SAP gives customers the flexibility to run SAP HANA Cloud on the infrastructure that best meets their needs. Today, it's available on the leading hyperscalers‚ÄîAmazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud Platform, and Alibaba Cloud‚Äîleveraging our partners' global reach and modern infrastructure. See SAP HANA Cloud data centers.

By adding SAP Cloud Infrastructure as a deployment option alongside the hyperscalers, we give customers even more choice and flexibility, while meeting requirements for technological autonomy, data residency, and access control in the public cloud.

First region and initial scope

SAP HANA Cloud is now live in the SAP BTP Europe (Frankfurt) region on SCI. This cloud-in-country deployment keeps customer and backup data local, ensuring data residency and compliance.

Operating in EU Access mode, the SCI-based deployment restricts the processing of personally identifiable customer data to SAP delivery units located within the European Economic Area (EEA) and Switzerland, giving customers enhanced control and data protection.

On SCI, SAP HANA Cloud delivers the same capabilities and benefits as on hyperscalers*, along with the same SLAs and pricing models, ensuring a consistent experience regardless of deployment choice.

What's next?

SAP HANA Cloud is expanding alongside SAP BTP into new SCI regions. Additional SCI regions are planned for upcoming releases‚Äîcheck the latest SAP HANA Cloud data center availability in SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Summary

With SAP HANA Cloud, customers can choose the infrastructure provider that best fits their business‚Äîeither a partner hyperscaler or SAP itself. The first SAP BTP region on SAP Cloud Infrastructure is Europe (Frankfurt). With EU-Access, in-country hosting, and enterprise-grade SLAs, this region provides compliance, security, and reliability, serving the specific needs of German and European customers.

*Restrictions at GA: (1) SAP HANA Cloud, Data lake Relational Engine, (2) Joule in SAP HANA Cloud Central, (3) Customer-managed encryption keys (CMK), and (4) memory sizes larger than 7.5 TB.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì Blog #4 in the Series
entry.content:
We‚Äôve been talking in this about how you can build your business case for modernizing to SAP HANA Cloud. However, many organizations still need help calculating the business value of migrating their database to the cloud.

A recent IDC study [1]  confirmed the value of modernizing to SAP HANA Cloud. Using a detailed business value assessmt methodology, IDC calculated that each SAP HANA Cloud database delivered US$820,000 in average annual benefits, with a 10.3-month payback on investment. Numbers like that are sure to turn heads.

This blog reviews the three beneficial features that can help you make the case for SAP HANA Cloud: native AI capabilities, built-in data integration, and automation that streamlines the duties of database developers and administrators.

Native AI capabilities

To gain value from huge volumes of business data, you need advanced AI capabilities that simplify the development and deployment of intelligent applications. 

SAP HANA Cloud is part of SAP Business Technology Platform, which offers powerful AI tools, frameworks, and services. These capabilities streamline the development and deployment of intelligent applications using machine learning and generative AI features. Extensive tools and resources, including prebuilt AI models, help you take advantage of business-ready AI.  

Multi-model engines process vast amounts of data and generate intelligent, in-context outputs. SAP HANA Cloud provides native storage, processing, and querying capabilities for AI data. A built-in vector engine handles embeddings as core data, so you can conduct similarity searches and rankings without creating separate vector databases. The database also supports retrieval-augmented generation, which helps large language models become more context-aware and integrate sensitive business context into data interactions.

SAP HANA Cloud also includes built-in, AI-enabled analytics that support predictive modeling, graph and similarity search, and time-series analysis. A predictive analysis library supports powerful features such as clustering, recommender systems, and outlier detection.  In addition, a library of 100+ business and scientific algorithms for key ML scenarios is embedded natively into the database. The IDC report suggests organizations can use these capabilities to automate insights and optimize decision-making by processing multiple data types. Study participants realized a 25% productivity increase, which translates into a value of $271,184 per enterprise.

Global cosmetics leader Natura &Co used the AI capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) to create a similarity search. The vector engine feature of SAP HANA Cloud allows users to extract information from large volumes of documents using natural language. The company also plans to use the generative AI capability to streamline business processes and support faster decision-making in its implementation of SAP S/4HANA.

Built-in data integration

Your IT landscape is complex‚Äîwith data flowing to and from multiple systems, cloud platforms, and on-premises environments. Bringing this data together has always required complex ETL processes, synchronization mechanisms, and data duplication efforts. How can you simplify the integration of this business data? Realistically, every business uses data sources provided by various vendors. To bring this data together requires smooth data integration.

SAP HANA Cloud offers native connectivity with almost any data source. You can access data from SAP and third-party applications, including ERP systems, IoT devices, and external data services. The database can gain live access to sources without data replication. This integration unifies disparate data streams and creates one holistic view of your enterprise data, allowing developers to build intelligent data applications that deliver accurate, current information in real time.  

Built-in data integration capabilities include:

  • Smart data access, offering virtual data access from source systems without physical data movement
  • Simple switching between virtual data access and data replication, balancing cost and performance effectively
  • Smart data integration, enabling real-time or batch data replication with transformation capabilities
  • Hybrid connectivity, with unified connection to on-premises SAP HANA systems

Multi-model capabilities combine federated relational data with other data types, including vector embedding, spatial information, graph relationships, and JSON documents. By eliminating traditional barriers between data sources and locations, SAP HANA Cloud helps you simplify data management while creating a connected enterprise data ecosystem.

In the IDC report, respondents said the ability to gain access to real-time data from a single source helped their analytics teams accelerate data reporting. One executive working in the retail industry said, ‚ÄúThe data is far more accessible and quicker to get with SAP HANA Cloud.‚Äù

Automation to streamline DBA duties

The workload of database developers and administrators seems to grow endlessly, as data architectures become more complex. Whether they are diagnosing and resolving issues, tuning database performance, or writing queries, these workers face a long list of highly manual tasks.

Using integrated, AI-powered tooling available with SAP HANA Cloud helps administrators work more efficiently and productively. Conversational AI features help them generate SQL statements from plain text queries, create intelligent explanations of database behaviors or issues, and automatically summarize alerts and system messages into actionable insights.

SAP HANA Cloud also automates routine database maintenance issues. The database continuously monitors system usage and offers proactive recommendations for optimization. It can identify performance bottlenecks, guide resource tuning, and suggest areas ripe for elastic scaling. Administrators can get the job done with no deep technical intervention required. 

The benefits of automation are notable. In the IDC study, companies reported a 30% efficiency boost for their database administrator (DBA) teams, resulting in an average annual business value of $336,089 per organization.

One technology organization appreciated this value. ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud provides our DBA team with more tools to help identify issues and resolve them,‚Äù said the participant. ‚ÄúIt has increased their productivity as a result.‚Äù

Another company in the agriculture industry concurred. ‚ÄúThe fact that SAP HANA Cloud has centralized database administration and provided flexibility to add a data lake within its data source connections has positively impacted the productivity of our DBA team,‚Äù the executive added.

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

Read the final blog to learn how comprehensive security and a complete development system can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

entry.content:
Credit: @Vitaliy-R Your startup blogs kindled my interest to explore working with Python in SAP ecosystem. Python in BAS and Jupyter in BAS 

When I first started exploring SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), I was curious about how Python could fit into the SAP landscape. I‚Äôve mostly associated BAS with HANA artefacts(SQLScript, hdbcalculationview, hdbreptask etc.) and CAP artefacts, so writing a Python script inside BAS felt like venturing into new territory. My goal was simple: write a basic script and connect it to SAP HANA Cloud. What I discovered along the way is that Python not only works smoothly in BAS but also makes it easy to interact with HANA Cloud, opening up opportunities for data exploration, automation, and integration in a way that feels both modern and approachable.

Before jumping into the Python script, I had to get my environment ready in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). Here‚Äôs what I set up:

A BAS dev space with a full-stack cloud application space since it supports multiple runtimes, including Python. I had a space with HANA Native Application type. Since the Python tools extension is not added by default, I edited the space to select the Python tools in the additional extension options. 

HANA Dev Space Python extension

 Note: For initial steps to check the Python version, Jupyter notebook and set ups refer to the blogs listed at the start. 

Use Case: I attempted to achieve the following: 

  • Establish a connection to HANA Cloud
  • Execute an SQL query on a table/view 
  • Display the results

In the BAS, I created a project from Template: SAP HANA Database Project

 

Next step: Create a notebook file. 

My guide to connect to HANA Cloud: Connect to HANA Cloud 

When I first tried importing hdbcli into my Jupyter Notebook within BAS, I ran into the same ModuleNotFoundError. Even though I had already installed hdbcli In the terminal, the notebook kernel wasn‚Äôt recognizing it. On some search and prompting with GPT( üòÅ), I understood that it's a common issue because Jupyter can run in a different Python environment than the terminal. The fix was simple: I ran

import sys
!{sys.executable} -m pip install hdbcli

directly in a notebook cell. This ensures that the HANA client is installed in the same environment as the notebook kernel. After this step, I could successfully import dbapi and connect to HANA Cloud without any errors. It was a small but important lesson about Python environments in BAS, especially when using Jupyter.

With the hdbcli package installed and working in my Jupyter Notebook, I was ready to write my first Python script to connect to SAP HANA Cloud.

In the next cell, I imported hdbcli in this notebook. 

import hdbcli
print(hdbcli.__file__)

 

 The next step was to gain access to the dbapi interface, which allows you to establish connections, execute SQL queries, and fetch results from your HANA Cloud instance. This simple import is the gateway to working with HANA directly from Python.

from hdbcli import dbapi

The next step is to establish a connection to your HANA Cloud instance. This requires specifying the host, port, username, and password.

 After connecting, you can create a cursor object to execute SQL statements. An SQL statement, preferably a Select Query to test the retrieval of data from HANA Cloud. In my case, I used a Select with count on the number of records in a view. Once the variables were ready, execute the connection cursor object.

Note: in the SQL variable, use single quotes and a semicolon at the end of the query. (beginner tip üôÇ )

Now is the time to test the data retrieval from the script and compare it with the Database Explorer.

Completing my first Python script in SAP Business Application Studio and connecting it to HANA Cloud was an exciting milestone. From the initial curiosity to the small hurdles like installing hdbcli in the notebook and finally seeing my script return results, every step felt like a mini victory.

That simple output from HANA Cloud made all the effort worthwhile and gave me a real sense of accomplishment.

This experience has sparked my curiosity to explore more complex queries, data analysis, and automation using Python in SAP.
